item.title: Afghanistan: UK's Kabul evacuation ends today, says military
item.description: It is "heartbreaking" not to have been able to evacuate everyone, says the head of the armed forces.

item.title: Covid: Delta variant patients twice as likely to need hospital care
item.description: Get double-jabbed to reduce this risk, advise experts who have studied different variants of the virus.

item.title: Husband and wife both win Paralympic gold for GB
item.description: Husband and wife Neil and Lora Fachie both win Paralympic gold for Britain on the last day of track cycling events in Tokyo.

item.title: Hire UK workers to drive lorries, minister tells firms
item.description: The business secretary rejects calls to relax immigration rules as companies struggle to fill vacancies.

item.title: UK's oldest living heart transplant patient marks 90th birthday
item.description: Ted Warner was only expected to live for eight more years after his operation in 1990.

item.title: Robert F Kennedy assassin Sirhan Sirhan recommended for parole
item.description: A parole board calls for Sirhan Sirhan's release, but the decision now goes to California's governor.

item.title: Government to ban single-use plastic cutlery
item.description: Plastic plates and polystyrene cups will also be banned in England in what ministers call a "war on plastic".

item.title: Covid origin: US spy agencies publish 'inconclusive' report
item.description: The office that oversees US spy agencies could not establish how the coronavirus pandemic began.

item.title: Canada election: Justin Trudeau rally cancelled after angry protests
item.description: Jeering crowds force the Canadian prime minister to call off an election campaign event.

item.title: Greenland island is world's northernmost island - scientists
item.description: They say a tiny island off Greenland's coast was discovered by luck during a recent expedition.

item.title: Covid-19: Lifeguards withdrawn from Lincolnshire beaches after positive case
item.description: Skegness, Ingoldmells, Sutton-on-Sea and Mablethorpe beaches have no lifeguards, the RNLI says.

item.title: 'Superstar' dog retires after six years of donating rare blood
item.description: Woodie the greyhound has given blood 22 times to help up to 88 other dogs.

item.title: The Papers: Brits die in Kabul and US prepares to strike back
item.description: The ongoing crisis and evacuation from Afghanistan leads many of this morning's front pages.

item.title: Paralympic cheats stopped me winning gold
item.description: British swimmer Dan Pepper says his career was ruined by the ban on intellectual impairment sports at the Paralympics after a cheating scandal in 2000.

item.title: ICYMI: Tank ballet, lederhosen and a brave swan
item.description: Stories you may have missed this week include Russian army games and a WWII bunker turned into a B&B.

item.title: Are South Africans running the Strictly dance floor?
item.description: As Strictly prepares to return to our screens next month another South African dancer has joined the professionals.

item.title: Week in pictures: 21 - 27 August 2021
item.description: A selection of powerful images from all over the globe, taken this week.

item.title: The UK's first all-black, all-female theatre company is shaking up Shakespeare
item.description: Mawa Theatre Company is a UK first and aims to make Shakespeare's work more accessible.

item.title: 'Murder Hornets': Nest of 1,500 eradicated in the US
item.description: A nest of the giant, invasive insects was the first destroyed in Washington this year.

item.title: Cristiano Ronaldo: How Man Utd pulled off shock transfer
item.description: BBC Sport's Simon Stone details the journey of Cristiano Ronaldo's shock return to Manchester United.

item.title: Festivals and Covid: A risk worth taking?
item.description: Some music fans accept they might catch Covid - but others are selling their tickets and staying away.

item.title: Does feeding garden birds do more harm than good?
item.description: How bird feeding could disrupt an ecological balance just beyond our windowsills and gardens.

item.title: Covid-19: The Indian children who have forgotten how to read and write
item.description: Schools in India have been closed for more than a year, with learning outcomes falling drastically.

item.title: Scotland's most remote school seeks new headteacher
item.description: The current head of the school on Fair Isle, which has just three pupils, is stepping down after 35 years.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Vigil: Submarine drama explores 'isolating and tense' life and death at sea
item.description: Suranne Jones and Martin Compston star in BBC One's Vigil, set on board a nuclear submarine.

item.title: The British teen who won wheelchair slalom at the 1964 Tokyo Paralympic Games
item.description: Caz Walton was 17 when she competed at the 1964 Paralympic Games in Tokyo and won gold.

item.title: DeChambeau shoots 60 to take lead in BMW Championship
item.description: Bryson DeChambeau cards a career-best 60 to take a one-shot lead in the BMW Championship in Baltimore.

item.title: British trio Raducanu, Boulter & Dart qualify for US Open
item.description: British trio Emma Raducanu, Katie Boulter and Harriet Dart reach the US Open women's singles main draw after winning their final qualifying matches.

item.title: England v India: Highlights as resilient India frustrate hosts
item.description: Watch highlights as England face a resurgent India and end day three of the third Test at Headingley 139 runs ahead with two days to go.

item.title: 'The Taliban killed my brother for protecting my family'
item.description: Saba says his family have gone into hiding after the Taliban threatened to kill his nephews.

item.title: Afghanistan: Shukria Barakzai's whispered voice notes and dramatic escape
item.description: The desperate messages sent by Afghan politician Shukria Barakzai to a UK MP. as the Taliban tried to hunt her down.

item.title: 'Overwhelming' help given for Afghan refugees in UK
item.description: "No-one chooses to be a refugee, if any of us were in that position I hope we would get support."

item.title: Afghanistan: How do the Taliban make money?
item.description: The Taliban maintain a sophisticated financial network and taxation system to generate income.

item.title: Afghanistan airport attack: Who are IS-K?
item.description: The jihadist group - set up in 2015 - is blamed for some of the worst atrocities in recent years.

item.title: Afghanistan: How much opium is produced and what's the Taliban's record?
item.description: The Taliban claims opium poppy cultivation was stopped when it last held power in Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: Why can't the UK hold Kabul airport without the US?
item.description: The US and UK have different timetables for the effort to evacuate people from Afghanistan

item.title: Afghanistan crisis: BBC News Special
item.description: Lyse Doucet in Kabul and Philippa Thomas in London present special coverage of Afghanistan's crisis.

item.title: Kabul airport attack: What do we know?
item.description: The bombing came hours after warnings to citizens to stay away from the airport, due to an imminent threat.

item.title: Kabul airport attack: 'I saw doomsday'
item.description: Afghans caught up in the twin blasts outside Kabul airport speak of the horror they witnessed.

item.title: Young Afghan mayor who fled Taliban hidden in car
item.description: One of Afghanistan's first female mayors, Zarifa Ghafari, describes her dramatic escape to Germany.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Jaco van Gass - from injury in Afghanistan to Paralympic champion
item.description: Twelve years ago, Jaco van Gass was fighting for his life after being injured in Afghanistan. Now he's a Paralympic champion.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Swimmers Hannah Russell and Reece Dunn land gold
item.description: Hannah Russell and debutant Reece Dunn both win swimming golds for Great Britain at the Tokyo Paralympics.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Who are Great Britain's medal winners?
item.description: A list of the Great Britain medal winners from the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics medal table - which country has won most golds?
item.description: Which country is leading the medal table for the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics? How are Great Britain getting on?

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: What you need to know about Paralympic classification
item.description: From KL1 to PT2 and F11 to SB6 - everything you need to know about classification at the Paralympic Games.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Sport-by-sport guide
item.description: Twenty-two sports will feature in the Tokyo Paralympics - find out more about them all here.

item.title: Bilal Sarwary: 'The plane hit the tower and all our lives changed'
item.description: Afghan journalist Bilal Sarwary was selling carpets when 9/11 happened. From that day on, everything changed.

item.title: Shot in the head in Angola, left for dead, now a Wetherspoons star
item.description: Cesar Kimbirima fled Angola after being shot four times and spending five months in a coma.

item.title: Michael Knighton: The man who could have bought Man Utd for £10m but walked away
item.description: In August 1989, Michael Knighton celebrated his Manchester United takeover deal at Old Trafford. But the plotting against him had just begun.

item.title: India's living dead: 'They stared at me like I was a ghost'
item.description: If you're dead you can't own land - so if someone obtains your death certificate you could lose everything.

item.title: Peter Karlsson: The painful verdict on Swedish ice hockey player's 1995 killing
item.description: Peter Karlsson was stabbed to death in the street. His killer said he was protecting himself - via the so-called 'gay panic' defence.
